message.content: This question tests our understanding of chemical changes and their effects on objects. When an object undergoes a chemical change, it will have new chemical properties. Option (C) is correct because adding lime to a soda will result in a chemical reaction, changing its taste and acidity. Option (A) is incorrect because adding water to a drink does not result in a chemical change, it is just a physical change. Option (B) is incorrect because adding bleach to a toilet is also a physical change, not a chemical change. Option (D) is incorrect because having hair in a sink does not lead to a chemical change either.

This question requires knowledge about chemical changes and how they affect the properties of substances. When an object undergoes a chemical change, it means that the chemical composition of the substance has changed, resulting in new chemical properties. Option (A) is unrelated because having water in a drink does not involve a chemical change. Option (B) is incorrect because adding bleach to a toilet does not result in a chemical change but rather a mixture. Option (D) is also incorrect because having hair in a sink does not involve a chemical change. Option (C) is the correct answer because adding lime to a soda can cause a chemical reaction, changing the taste and properties of the soda.

This question requires knowledge about chemical changes and how they affect the properties of substances. When an object undergoes a chemical change, it means that its chemical composition is altered, resulting in new chemical properties. In the given options, adding lime to a soda would cause a chemical reaction, changing the composition and properties of the soda. Options (A) and (D) do not involve chemical changes, they only involve mixtures of different substances. Option (B) involves a chemical reaction between bleach and the components of a toilet, but it does not result in new chemical properties of the toilet.

This question requires knowledge about chemical changes and their effects on the properties of substances. When an object undergoes a chemical change, its chemical properties change. Option (A) is incorrect because adding water to a drink does not necessarily result in a new chemical property. Option (B) is incorrect because adding bleach to a toilet does not change its chemical properties, but rather its cleaning properties. Option (D) is unrelated to the question as it does not involve a chemical change. Option (C) is the correct answer because adding lime to a soda introduces a new chemical property - a change in taste due to the reaction between the lime and the soda.

This question requires some knowledge about chemical changes and the resulting new chemical properties. When an object undergoes a chemical change, it means that its molecular structure has been altered and it has new chemical properties. Option (C) is correct because adding lime to a soda changes its chemical composition and introduces new properties such as a different taste or acidity. Option (A) is incorrect because having water in a drink is not a chemical change. Option (B) is incorrect because having bleach in a toilet is not a chemical change, it is just a mixture. Option (D) is incorrect because having hair in a sink is not a chemical change, it is just a physical presence.

This question assesses understanding of chemical changes and their effects on the properties of objects. When an object undergoes a chemical change, it means that new substances are formed with different chemical properties. In this case, adding lime to a soda would cause a chemical change, resulting in the formation of a new substance with different properties. Options (A), (B), and (D) do not involve a chemical change, but rather the addition of different substances to an object without causing a chemical reaction.

This question requires knowledge about chemical changes and chemical properties. When an object undergoes a chemical change, it means that the composition of the object has changed and new substances are formed. Option (C) is correct because adding lime to a soda would result in a chemical change, creating new chemical properties by altering the taste and composition of the soda. Option (A) is incorrect because a drink with water in it does not undergo a chemical change, as water is a common component of many drinks. Option (B) is incorrect because a toilet with bleach in it also does not undergo a chemical change, as bleach is added for cleaning purposes. Option (D) is incorrect because a sink with hair in it also does not undergo a chemical change, as hair is a physical substance that does not alter the chemical properties of the sink.

Chemical change refers to a process where a substance is transformed into one or more different substances with new chemical properties. Option (C) is the correct answer because mixing soda with lime creates a chemical reaction that produces carbon dioxide, resulting in a fizzy drink with new chemical properties. Option (A) is incorrect because simply adding water to a drink does not result in a chemical change. Option (B) is incorrect because mixing bleach with water in a toilet does not result in a chemical change but rather a mixture. Option (D) is incorrect because a sink with hair in it does not undergo a chemical change, but rather a physical change due to the presence of a foreign substance.

This question requires basic knowledge about chemical changes and their effects on objects. When an object undergoes a chemical change, it means that its chemical composition has been altered, resulting in new chemical properties. In this case, option (C) is the correct answer because adding lime to a soda will result in a chemical change, creating new chemical properties in the soda. Option (A) is incorrect because adding water to a drink does not result in a chemical change, as water is a common component in many drinks. Option (B) is also incorrect because a toilet with bleach in it does not undergo a chemical change, only a physical change (bleach mixing with water). Option (D) is also incorrect because a sink with hair in it does not undergo a chemical change, only a physical change (accumulation of hair in the drain).

This question requires knowledge about chemical changes and their effects on the properties of substances. When an object undergoes a chemical change, it means that its chemical composition has changed and new substances with new properties are formed. In this case, option (C) is the correct answer because when you add lime to a soda, it undergoes a chemical change and new compounds are formed, altering the taste and properties of the soda. Option (A) refers to a mixture and not a chemical change. Options (B) and (D) are mixtures as well, and do not involve chemical changes.

This question requires basic knowledge about chemical changes and the resulting chemical properties. When an object undergoes a chemical change, it means that the composition of the substance has changed and new chemical properties have been formed. Option (C) is the correct answer because adding lime to a soda creates a chemical reaction that results in new chemical properties and flavors. Option (A) is incorrect because a drink with water in it does not represent a chemical change, as water itself is not undergoing a chemical reaction. Option (B) is incorrect because mixing bleach with a toilet does not result in a chemical change, it is simply a mixture of chemicals. Option (D) is incorrect because a sink with hair in it does not represent a chemical change, it is only a physical change where the sink is being clogged.

This question tests understanding of chemical changes and how they affect the properties of a substance. When an object undergoes a chemical change, it means that the chemical composition of the substance has changed, leading to new chemical properties. In this case, adding lime to a soda would result in a chemical change because it would create a reaction between the lime and the soda. This reaction would alter the taste, pH level, and other chemical properties of the soda. The other options are either not related to chemical changes (options A and D) or not likely to cause a chemical change (option B).

This question requires basic knowledge about chemical changes and how they affect the properties of substances. When an object undergoes a chemical change, new chemical properties are formed. In this case, option (C) is correct because adding lime to a soda would cause a chemical change, resulting in new chemical properties. Lime contains citric acid, which reacts with the ingredients in the soda to create a new flavor and composition. Options (A), (B), and (D) are incorrect because they do not involve chemical changes or the formation of new chemical properties.

Option (C) is the correct answer because by adding lime to a soda, a chemical reaction occurs that changes the taste and properties of the soda. Options (A), (B), and (D) do not involve a chemical change that leads to new chemical properties.

The other options are either describing a mixture (option A, a drink with water in it) or physical changes (options B and D, involving bleach and hair, respectively) which do not result in new chemical properties.

Option (C) is the correct answer because adding lime to a soda causes a chemical change, changing the taste and acidity of the soda. This question requires basic knowledge about chemical changes and their effects on the properties of objects. When an object undergoes a chemical change, it will have new chemical properties. Option (C) is the correct answer because when lime is added to soda, it undergoes a chemical change and the properties of the soda change (e.g. it might become more acidic). Options (A), (B), and (D) are all examples of physical changes, where the properties of the objects might change but not due to a chemical reaction. For example, adding water to a drink or hair to a sink does not result in a chemical change. Bleach in a toilet might clean it, but it's not a chemical change to the bleach or the toilet.
